Shades of the 1987 "Max Headroom" transmitter hijacking in Chicago, but with a much more serious purpose.

Though this doesn't look like it was done by taking over an OTA STL; the transitions are too clean and immediate. Likely done by hacking into a networked content server.

Background: broadcast transmitters are typically unattended and located on a hilltop or tower farm, away from the studio where programming originates. Content is fed to the transmitter via a "studio-transmitter link (STL)", generally microwave, often now with an internet backup.

The "Max Headroom" hack was done by parking a rogue (analog) STL transmitter near the Chicago stations transmitter sites, overwhelming the real STL signals from the studios. The rogue signal then was what went over the air on the stations.

But broadcasters, especially local stations in smaller markets, don't always prioritize IT and engineering, and transmitter equipment is typically amortized over many years. So something similar is likely still possible in some places.
